text:
- The story keeps
changing again and again.

Back now to that meeting between
Donald Trump's inner circle

and a Russian
attorney last summer.

CNN has now learned
that there were

others in the room besides
those previously reported.

And some of their
identities remain a mystery.

President Trump's son, Donald
Trump, Jr., helped coordinate
the meeting by email.

And some say that paper trail
could be a game changer.

Those emails, of course, have
been in the headlines all week.

They're the strongest
indication yet

that the Trump team
was willing to accept
help from the Kremlin.

We want to remind you now
about just how things unfolded.

"The New York Times"
first reported

the story, and
Trump, Jr.'s response

to it evolved with
each passing day.

By Tuesday, he released
the email chain himself,
setting off shock waves.

It showed that he'd agreed to
meet with someone described

as a Russian
government attorney who

was part of an official effort
to help his father's campaign.

The fallout was
swift and fierce.

Hillary Clinton's former
running mate didn't mince words.

TIM KAINE: We're now beyond
obstruction of justice in terms
of what's being investigated.

This is moving into perjury,
false statements, and even
into potentially treason.

- Trump, Jr. went on a
friendly cable network
to deny wrongdoing.

And he told Fox
News he just wanted

to, quote, "hear them out, play
it out, and see what happens."

He says that he learned
nothing, but didn't directly
answer this key question.

- Did you tell your father
anything about this?
DONALD TRUMP, JR.: No.

It was such a nothing,
there was nothing to tell.

I wouldn't have even
remembered it until you start
scouring through the stuff.

It was literally just a wasted
20 minutes, which was a shame.

- A shame the meeting
wasn't as promised.

And that same day, we saw signs
that the Republican defense

of Mr. Trump was
beginning to crack.

The head of a powerful
House committee

slammed the Trump
camp for their, quote,
"amnesia" and demanded action.

- Someone close to the president
needs to get everyone connected

with that campaign in a
room and say, from the time

you saw "Doctor Zhivago"
until the moment

you drank vodka with
a guy named Boris,

you list every
single one of those.

And we're gonna turn them
over to the special counsel.

- On Wednesday, we heard
that the White House
was paralyzed by all the chaos.

That night, Mr.
Trump left for Paris,

where he defended his son during
a news conference the next day.

DONALD TRUMP: I have a son
who is a great young man.
He's a fine person.

He took a meeting with
a lawyer from Russia.

It lasted for a
very short period,
and nothing came of the meeting.

And I think it's a meeting
that most people in politics
probably would have taken.

- That did not go over well with
some lawmakers, who insisted

Trump, Jr. and the others
should have reported
the Russian effort to the FBI.

A top Democrat also
cast blame on Mr.
Trump's fellow Republicans.

NANCY PELOSI:
Republicans in Congress

have become enablers of
the Trump-Russia assault
on our democracy.

- On Thursday, we learned
Trump, Jr. will be called

to testify before
Senate investigators,
perhaps as early as next week.

They also want
information from Jared

Kushner, the only current
White House staffer
who was in that meeting.

One senator told CNN
what they want to know.

ANGUS KING: What
about future meetings

and future relationships
and future connections?
And we don't know that yet.
Is this an isolated incident?

Or is it the tip of an
information iceberg?

- One prominent conservative
summed up the week

by saying that the
Russian scandal

has entered a new phase,
and there's no going back.

But President Trump still has
plenty of supporters who say
it's all a partisan witch hunt.

Well, to get more on this,
let's bring in Larry Sabato,
who is live for us in Virginia.

He is the director
of the University

of Virginia Center for
Politics, as well as an author.

Thank you so much
for your time, Larry.

The story's obviously
evolving rapidly,

with new information
coming forth every day
about this June 2016 meeting.

Is this latest
information about this

lobbyist, this
American-Russian lobbyist

that was in this meeting,
is this a game changer?

LARRY SABATO: Well,
it certainly has

been, even for some conservative
commentators and Trump

supporters, who've
said that it's

the first real direct evidence
that there might have been

some collusion or that some key
people were seeking collusion

with Russia to get information
to use against Hillary Clinton.
That's almost undeniable now.

And remember, up
until this point,

many people on the Trump
side were insisting
that it was all just smoke.

And once the smoke cleared,
there would be nothing there.
Not true.

- How significant is it, Larry,
that some GOP lawmakers have

now started to
voice their opinions

on this and their,
frankly, disgust
in some cases for this meeting?

How significant is it that
this is happening now?
LARRY SABATO: It's significant.

But everybody's waiting for all
of these Republican lawmakers

in the House and Senate
who are criticizing Trump

and suggesting that there
may be something here

on Russia to actually
do something.
Words are useful.
But actions are more useful.

And to this point,
very few Republicans

have ever been able or willing
to cast a vote against Donald

Trump or take a specific
action against the Trump
administration.
So we'll see.

- Why do you suppose
this is, that so few are

willing, as you say,
to come out and overtly
criticize or take action?

LARRY SABATO: You
suggested it in your setup.

You said there are a
lot of the Trump base,

and that's about 40% of
America, totally uninterested
in this subject.

And even if there were photos
of Vladimir Putin handing

information to Donald
Trump and Trump

handing information back to
Putin, they would dismiss it.
They would ignore it.

The reason those Republican
lawmakers won't come out and do

something is because
they fear the Trump base
in their own party primaries.

They can lose their
reelection races there.

- You talk about on your
website, the Crystal Ball,

similarities between
the voters for Reagan,

President Reagan,
and President Trump.

So how could, perhaps,
someone use information

like this to better
understand the voters

and, if they need to, how to
sway them from their adoration
at this point?

LARRY SABATO: It's
intensity level.

You can have support,
and then you can have
support, underlined, all caps.

And Trump, like Reagan, has
that support in all caps.

It takes an awful
lot to weaken it.
It actually did for Nixon.

It took two and a half years
of investigation, of work

on Watergate, and lots
of journalistic scoops

and all the rest of
it, plus a Senate

investigation that really caught
fire, and court decisions.
All of this played into it.
Took a long time.

It could take just as
long, if not longer,

in this investigation of
the Trump administration.

- And obviously,
the investigation
continues to unfold.
New developments every day.
We do appreciate your time.

Larry Sabato live for
us there in Virginia.

He's the director of the
University of Virginia
Center for Politics.
Thank you.
